'''''Hericium abietis''''',<ref>''Abietis'', "of ''[[Abies]]''", the fir genus.</ref> commonly known as the '''bear's head''' or the '''western coral hedgehog''', is an [[edible mushroom]] in the [[tooth fungus]] group. It grows on [[conifer]] stumps or logs in North America, producing a cream white [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] up to {{convert|10|–|75|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} tall and  wide. It fruits from after the start of the fall rains to mid-season.

==Taxonomy==
The species was first described as ''Hydnum abietis'' by American botanist [[James Robert Weir]] in 1931. Weir collected the [[type (biology)|type]] specimens in 1916, near the [[Priest River (Idaho)|Priest River]] in [[Idaho]]. [[Kenneth Archibald Harrison]] transferred it to the genus ''[[Hericium]]'' in 1964.<ref name="Harrison 1964"/> The mushroom is commonly known as the "bear's head"<ref name="Tylutki II 1987"/> or the "western coral hedgehog".<ref name="McKnight 1987"/>

==Description==

[[File:Hericium abietis mushroom 2018.jpg|thumb|''Hericium abietis'' mushroom growing on a log in Northwestern British Columbia. Note, there is also a bracket mushroom growing in the background on the same log.]]

The fruit body forms a compact, branched mass with long spines hanging down. The branches originate from a single, thick, tough base. The color of the fruit body ranges from white to creamy, light yellowish, to [[salmon (color)|salmon]]-[[buff (color)|buff]]. The hanging spines are usually {{convert|0.5|–|1|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} long, although some may be as long as {{convert|2.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}; they are soft and brittle, and typically grow as clusters at the tips of the branches. Typically, fruit bodies have dimensions in the range of {{convert|10|to|75|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} tall and  wide, but they have been known to attain massive sizes; one noted specimen was about {{convert|100|lb|kg}}.<ref name="Arora 1986"/>

''Hericium abietis'' produces a white [[spore print]]. [[Spore]]s are spherical or nearly so, smooth to slightly roughened, [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]], and measure 4.5–5.5 by 4–5 [[micrometre|μm]].<ref name="Arora 1986"/> The [[hypha]]e are monomitic (consisting of only generative hyphae), and they have [[clamp connection]]s.<ref name="Tylutki II 1987"/>

===Similar species===
''[[Hericium erinaceus]]'' is a lookalike spine fungus. It can be distinguished by its more compact fruit body structure that lacks multiple branches, in which the hanging spines all originate from a single thick [[tubercle]].<ref name="Tylutki II 1987"/> In ''[[Hericium coralloides]]'', the spines line the undersides of the branches, unlike ''H. abietis'', whose spines are arranged in clusters at the tip of branches.<ref name="Bessette 1987"/>

===Edibility===
''Hericium abietis'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]] and choice. [[David Arora]] suggests that cooking the mushroom produces a flavor similar to fish, and that it is suitable for [[saute]]ing, [[marinate|marinating]], or preparing as a [[curry (dish)|curry]] dish.<ref name="Arora 1986"/>

==Habitat and distribution==
''Hericium abietis'' causes a [[white pocket rot]] of [[conifer]]s; this is a form of [[wood-decay fungus|wood decay]] featuring a selective attack on [[lignin]] and [[hemicellulose]] in wood.<ref name="Tylutki II 1987"/> The fruit bodies grow singly or occasionally in small groups on the dead wood of conifers, especially [[fir]] and [[Douglas fir]].<ref name="Arora 1986"/> It can also be cultivated on conifer sawdust.<ref name="Xiao 1997"/> The species is found throughout North America.<ref name="Bessette 1987"/>
